text: Bon Appetit equally shared parenting or
ESP as we like to call it is the
purposeful sharing of all aspects of
running the home in the family what's
different about it is that we try to be
equal breadwinners there's no primary
breadwinner and less important career
then we try to be equal parents there's
no primary parent and help our parents
there's no primary person maintaining
our home there's no helper around the
house and we both have an equivalent
amount of time for recreation time for
you know togetherness in times of fun
Tuesdays and Thursdays at daddy days
the way we structure our lives is such a
way that I work five days a week but
work has allowed me to get off early on
Tuesdays and Thursdays so I get out at
noon I quickly jump on my bike come home
take a quick shower pick up vo at
daycare and then we spend the rest of
the afternoon together and then I we
come home and we play for about an hour
or so and then I pick up my kindergarten
at about 220 and then from there we play
in the yard we do we play in the sandbox
we go for bike rides we just scooting on
the street we run errands if need be we
prepared dinner getting ready for one
amy gets home about 5:30 oh yeah as your
day
you
who's coming more people are coming
right so today is mommy day which is a
Friday thing and that means that I am
NOT at my work I work four days a week
I'm at home with vo in the mornings and
then I get to be home with both kids in
the afternoon lets me have a great
balance between work and hanging out
with these guys and really knowing what
they're thinking and what they're up to
so mommy days are very special and
precious to me people often ask us well
how do you do it what do you how do you
divide things what do you divide and how
xxxx exactly do divide them and it's
tempting to answer with all the
specifics for example we usually try to
make it come out even that we each do
about the same amount of laundry we each
do about the same amount of cooking we
about the same amount of shopping for
food but that's not really the essence
of what we're talking about we were more
interested in the philosophy of being
teammates week we are with teammates and
trying to walk through our life together
and figure out a way that works best for
us so we can both have time for
recreation and time to be with the kids
so what if you asked us today what is
important to us and splitting things up
it's gonna be very different than what
we would answer three months from now
even because we would come up with a
solution for instance laundry okay so we
had a little problem when maybe thought
she was doing more laundry than me and
we worked out a system where I now do
all the dark one which she does all the
late laundry so that's the problem
that's now solved we don't need to worry
about it we don't need to know each
other about who's gonna do laundry and
when so three months ago I'll be working
on something totally different we're not
trying to maximize our income as a
family or as individuals we're trying to
optimize our life we've intentionally
chosen to scale back our careers we both
work about 30 hours a week in that has
fluctuated over time maybe a little more
maybe a little less depends on what we
can work out with our employers but we
think that kind of takes the edge off
what we see in many parents around us a
lot of people are stressed out rushing
home trying to get the daycare picked up
trying to get home cook dinner don't
have time with their kids and all of
that we're trying to avoid as much of
that as possible to create a sense of
stability
just relaxation and calmness for our
kids I think one of the hardest things
for women to embrace about equally
shared parenting is how deeply you have
to believe in letting go and trusting
your partner and I am far from perfect
at this I like to encourage her I still
don't like the idea of mark planning the
kids birthday parties or mark making
their Halloween costumes which I love to
do or mark I love seeing the look on her
face when I put green striped pants and
orange plaid on the kids in the morning
yeah I've gotten past mark dressing the
kids I mean that is it is what it is and
he's you know the kids are safe the kids
are warm the kids are clothed and I have
to do a lot of letting go because the
world says that reflects on the mother
and I have to say you know I put on my
nose at the world and say um no I
doesn't have to it doesn't have to as
long as the kids are are loved and cared
for nurtured by their parents then we're
doing great it's not for me to be the
director of Mark and not for Mark to be
my helper we and we are not prescribing
equally shared parenting for every
family in America we don't believe it's
the best or even the most desired
lifestyle model we think it works for us
and we would like to make this an option
for people something they would think
about when they think about how to
structure their lives
